newsitem.title: USA: Bond prices fall after 2-1/2-month-long rally.
newsitem.headline: Bond prices fall after 2-1/2-month-long rally.

text.p: Treasury prices fell sharply Thursday as investors, wary on the eve of the key monthly U.S. employment report, locked in profits from a rally that has lasted more than two months.

"People have a lot of profits, but they held off taking them because of hopes the market would improve," explained Michelle Laughlin, chief Treasury market strategist at Prudential Securities Inc. When that did not happen, investors booked those profits, she said.
"We have probably seen the highs for the time being," added Jim Kenney, head trader at Prudential.

The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond tumbled 1-15/32, or $14.6875 on a $1,000 bond. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 6.51 percent -- the highest since Nov. 8 close -- from 6.40 percent at Wednesday's close.

The market's hopes had rested on the possibility that the Federal Reserve would finally meet a seasonal need to add reserves to the banking system by buying Treasury notes and bonds in the open market. Such a move, called a coupon pass, tends to push up bond prices.
"When that didn't happen, they had to give up hope," said Patrick Dimick, government bond strategist at UBS Securities LLC. And, as bond futures fell, the cash market followed.
Investors were also nervous before the November employment report out Friday.

Payroll growth of about 180,000 jobs is widely expected, but a few economists forecast gains of 200,000 or more, which would support the view that the economy might pick up in the fourth quarter after slowing in the third.
Moreover, the market lacked fresh "good news" to justify a further rise in bond prices, analysts said.

"The market has run out of gas for short-term upward momentum," said Greg Carr, market analyst at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. "We were bumping our heads against levels that we couldn't justify unless we had an expectation that the Fed was going to ease (interest rates)."
With nothing yet to go on that could justify such a move by the central bank, the market was ripe for a sell-off, analysts said.
The bond market, which hates inflation, began its latest surge when the Fed left interest rates unchanged at its September policy meeting.
The 30-year bond yield began falling from more than 7 percent as a stream of government reports showed steady economic growth with inflation under control.
